post_text:
I had the opportunity to go to the One Act Play Regional Competition and the cast and crew from BHS were fantastic! Congratulations on your performance and recognition for placing as the regional runners up.

We had a number of students place in their Skills USA Competition. The Gold medal recipients will have the opportunity to move on and compete at the National Skills USA Challenge.
Gold Medals
1. Carlie Boyles Career Pathways: Health Services
2. Lauren Greenlaw Early Childhood Education
Bronze Medals
1. Jordan Wadleigh Diesel Equipment Technology
2. Mavis Taungatu'a Health Occupation Professional Portfolio
3. Alyssa Varnum Job Interview

Congratulation to all of you and good luck in the next level of competition.

post_text: Last evening the RSU 25 School Board held its' first budget workshop to begin discussions for the upcoming 2016-2017 school year. The focus of the evening was the presentation of the expense side of the first draft of the budget. The first draft represented a 1.77% increase in the PK-12 budget. The next budget workshop will be held on March 21st at 6 PM in the high school library.

post_text: Last evening, Lydia Carter, Cadence Hill, and Abby Wilson presented their data notebooks to members of the Curriculum Steering Committee. The young ladies use the data books, along with their teacher Mrs. Jones, to track their performance on the English and math standards. All present were impressed with how the girls understood the the standards and could articulate their progress toward proficiency.

post_text:
The Bucksport High School drama club, chorus and jazz combo will be hosting “Performing Arts Night” on Friday, February 26 at the Bucksport Performing Arts Center (at Bucksport Middle School.) The evening begins at 7 PM with the BHS Chorus performing selections from the Broadway musical “Rent” followed by some great jazz presented by the Bucksport High Jazz Combo.
The evening will conclude with the BHS Drama Club’s presentation of the one act comedy, “The Greek Mythology Olympiaganza” by Don Zolidis. The performance is appropriate for all ages. Admission is by donation.

post_text: Congratulations to the BHS Jazz Combo for qualifying for the upcoming State Jazz competition! Yesterday the group received a "1" rating from the judges at the regional competition. A "1" rating is the highest category of rating that can be earned. If you have a chance, you can see this outstanding combo perform this evening at the Bucksport Performing Arts Center along with the chorus and the performance of the one act play.

post_text: On Tuesday we hosted Education Week's reporter Sarah Sparks. She was here to research and learn about Bucksport High School and the BARR Program. Ms. Sparks spent the day observing the progam in practice, talking with students, and teachers. As an observer to the day I was pleased to see how much this program has influenced the culture of our school in a positve way.

Ms. Sparks spent the day observing the progam in practice, talking with students, and teachers. As an observer to the day I was pleased to see how much this program has influenced the culture of our school in a positve way.

post_text: We had a busy week last week hosting six school disticts who came to the high school on Friday to observe the BARR program in action. RSU 25 continues to be a hub for schools to understand the positve impacts of this program and we consistently recieve positive feedback from our visitors. I am looking forward to hosting Sarah Sparks, who is a writer for Education Week. Ms. Sparks is doing a story on the BARR program and will be visiting Bucksport High School this Tuesday as part of the story development.

post_text:
The schools are open and classes have begun for the 2015-2016 year. Special thanks to the facilities and maintenance department for their efforts in preparing and maintaining our facilities.

As we complete the first couple of days and begin to settle into the routine of school we begin the year I have been very pleased with the preparation by the teaching and support staff in each of the buildings. There is a very positive tone and energy in each of the buildings.

Opening student numbers:
Jewett School - 108
Miles Lane School - 306
Bucksport Middle School - 342
Bucksport High School- 315

The total of 1070 is on par with last year's opening numbers and up from last spring's April 1 count.

The total of 1070 is on par with last year's opening numbers and up from last spring's April 1 count.

post_text:
Last week the Governor vetoed LD 550 and I am pleased to share the veto was overridden in the House of Representatives yesterday (114-26) and in the Senate today (32-2). As such the bill becomes law and the clarification we sought in the sudden and severe language will be in law immediately.

This was a challenging proposition and we were greatly supported by Rep. Dick Campbell and Sen. Kim Rosen. Additionally, Rep Stanley of East Millinocket and Sen. Brian Langley of Ellsworth provided great guidance and support.

This will now clarify the definition of sudden and severe, particularly the segment of the law defining how the revenue service will calculate the mill rate comparison. In short, it will assist Bucksport to qualify for additional general purpose aid by lowering the community's valuation to recognize to loss of the mill and base the general purpose aid calculation on the new value in whole and not over the next four years.
text:
Last week the Governor vetoed LD 550 and I am pleased to share the veto was overridden in the House of Representatives yesterday (114-26) and in the Senate today (32-2). As such the bill becomes law and the clarification we sought in the sudden and severe language will be in law immediately.

This was a challenging proposition and we were greatly supported by Rep. Dick Campbell and Sen. Kim Rosen. Additionally, Rep Stanley of East Millinocket and Sen. Brian Langley of Ellsworth provided great guidance and support.

This will now clarify the definition of sudden and severe, particularly the segment of the law defining how the revenue service will calculate the mill rate comparison. In short, it will assist Bucksport to qualify for additional general purpose aid by lowering the community's valuation to recognize to loss of the mill and base the general purpose aid calculation on the new value in whole and not over the next four years.

Voting polls will be open in each of our communities and absentee ballots will be available through the town offices.

post_text: Tomorrow evening at 7PM the school board will hold the district budget meeting in the performing arts center. The district budget meeting is the next step in the budget adoption process where the budget warrant is presented to the public in attendance and a vote is taken on each of the budget articles. This meeting is open to all voting residents in the communities of Bucksport, Orland, Prospect, and Verona Island. The outcome of this meeting will determine the budget presented for the validation vote on June 9th. If you are a resident of these communities you are welcome to attend and participate.

The outcome of this meeting will determine the budget presented for the validation vote on June 9th. If you are a resident of these communities you are welcome to attend and participate.

post_text: Interesting day yesterday in Augusta where we continue to work LD 550. We will be back at it today as the taxation committee will take up 550 as amended. The passing of this bill will be of great assistance for the Town of Bucksport's application for "sudden and severe" relief adjustments for calculations using community valuation. A prime example is the calculation of general purpose aid for education.
text: Interesting day yesterday in Augusta where we continue to work LD 550. We will be back at it today as the taxation committee will take up 550 as amended. The passing of this bill will be of great assistance for the Town of Bucksport's application for "sudden and severe" relief adjustments for calculations using community valuation. A prime example is the calculation of general purpose aid for education.

post_text: We are continuing to work through the legislative process to clarify current language in the Maine statutes that will assist the Town of Bucksport to qualify for sudden and severe relief due to the closing of the mill. Thanks to the efforts of our legislative contingent and their sponsorship of bills, and our continued conversations and testimony we still have two bills in place. The picture below is form yesterday from the chambers of the taxation committee. We will be back in Augusta today for a work session in the education committee.
text: We are continuing to work through the legislative process to clarify current language in the Maine statutes that will assist the Town of Bucksport to qualify for sudden and severe relief due to the closing of the mill. Thanks to the efforts of our legislative contingent and their sponsorship of bills, and our continued conversations and testimony we still have two bills in place. The picture below is form yesterday from the chambers of the taxation committee. We will be back in Augusta today for a work session in the education committee.

post_text: I am very pleased to announce, by unanimous action of the School Board, Bill Tracy was elected as the next principal of Bucksport High School. Bill returns to BHS after serving as the principal of Mt. View High School in RSU 3. He will officially begin July 1, 2015, but transition planning will begin immediately.
text: I am very pleased to announce, by unanimous action of the School Board, Bill Tracy was elected as the next principal of Bucksport High School. Bill returns to BHS after serving as the principal of Mt. View High School in RSU 3. He will officially begin July 1, 2015, but transition planning will begin immediately.

post_text: I appreciated the students from the National Honor Society and the Student Council meeting with me this morning before school. The purpose of the meeting was to seek their input for the qualities and characteristics they value as we search for the next principal for BHS. This group will also go back the rest of the student body to solicit their feedback. The feedback will be used as part of the screening tool when we interview candidates.

post_text: Along with budget season, this is legislative season and I will be in Augusta again today for the work session in the Education Committee when they discuss LD 1152. In their last work session I was very pleased when the Maine Revenue Service publically recognized the sudden and severe statute in Chapter 36 section 208 and defined how that interplays with general purpose aid for education. This recognition supports the efforts by the Town of Bucksport to have the lost valuation created by the mill closing to be fully recognized sooner than fiscal year 2019. Should the Maine Revenue Service recognize Bucksport's sudden and severe application the lost valuation will be fully recognized in fiscal year 2017. Much work left to do, but this was certainly a positive turn of events.
text: Along with budget season, this is legislative season and I will be in Augusta again today for the work session in the Education Committee when they discuss LD 1152. This recognition supports the efforts by the Town of Bucksport to have the lost valuation created by the mill closing to be fully recognized sooner than fiscal year 2019. Should the Maine Revenue Service recognize Bucksport's sudden and severe application the lost valuation will be fully recognized in fiscal year 2017. Much work left to do, but this was certainly a positive turn of events.

post_text: This school board held another budget workshop last evening to continue its work on the 2016 school budget. Discussions last evening included the reduction of district guidance by .5 fte, elimination of the .5 fte middle school Spanish position, reduction of 70K from the capital improvement lines, reduction of JV sports. The reductions made last evening combined with previous work brings the budget to $13,802,000. The school board did take the position to maintain the woodworking program at the high school. To date, the board has reduced the proposed budget by more than $250,000 and as it stands now the budget is $130,000 below the FY 15 budget. Work will continue on the budget in preparation for the district budget meeting which will be held May 28th. The next school board meeting will be held April 28th.
text: This school board held another budget workshop last evening to continue its work on the 2016 school budget. Discussions last evening included the reduction of district guidance by .5 fte, elimination of the .5 fte middle school Spanish position, reduction of 70K from the capital improvement lines, reduction of JV sports. The reductions made last evening combined with previous work brings the budget to $13,802,000. The school board did take the position to maintain the woodworking program at the high school. To date, the board has reduced the proposed budget by more than $250,000 and as it stands now the budget is $130,000 below the FY 15 budget. Work will continue on the budget in preparation for the district budget meeting which will be held May 28th. The next school board meeting will be held April 28th.

post_text: I spent the morning yesterday in Augusta testifying on behalf of LD 550 which is a bill that would provide relief to Bucksport and reduce the town's valuation this year. The reduction in the valuation would be advantageous because it would allow additional general purpose aid for education in our next fiscal year. The overarching challenge is the language for sudden loss of valuation has been removed from the education funding formula and as it stands now the loss of community valuation associated with the closure of the mill will not be fully recognized until Fiscal Year 2019. This issue is important to Bucksport and RSU 25, but it is also important to all communities in the State. The removal of sudden loss language is an oversight that needs to be corrected.
text: I spent the morning yesterday in Augusta testifying on behalf of LD 550 which is a bill that would provide relief to Bucksport and reduce the town's valuation this year. The reduction in the valuation would be advantageous because it would allow additional general purpose aid for education in our next fiscal year. The overarching challenge is the language for sudden loss of valuation has been removed from the education funding formula and as it stands now the loss of community valuation associated with the closure of the mill will not be fully recognized until Fiscal Year 2019. This issue is important to Bucksport and RSU 25, but it is also important to all communities in the State. The removal of sudden loss language is an oversight that needs to be corrected.

Congratulations to our Bucksport High School students who earned medals at the recent SkillsUSA competition. BHS had five students earn medals in this competition designed to challenge their vocational skills and knowledge. Four of these students, who earned gold or silver medals, have qualified to participate in the national SkillsUSA competition that will be held in Louisville Kentucky during the last week of June.

Our medalist:

Aislynn McCafferty Gold Medal Promotional Bulletin Board
Gage Hanson Gold Medal Promotional Bulletin Board
Carlie Boyles Gold Medalist Health Services
Dylan Soper Silver Medalist Prepared Speech
Natalie Gray Bronze Medalist Early Childhood Education

post_text: We will be returning to full programming at the Jewett School tomorrow March 6th. The clean up is complete and all systems are working.
text: We will be returning to full programming at the Jewett School tomorrow March 6th. The clean up is complete and all systems are working.

post_text: The Jewett School will remain closed tomorrow March 5th. The problem we have experienced has been caused by a blockage in the sewer pipe located in the back of the school running towards Pine Street. The blockage has be cleared and all systems are functioning properly. However, there was a back up into the cellar area located below the stage. We have contracted a professional cleaning company to clean and deodorize the area where the back up occurred. The cleaning crew began work today and will be completed Thursday. We anticipate the Jewett School will be in session Friday. Teachers will again report to the central office on Thursday and ed techs will report to their designated assignments in the other schools.

post_text:
At Tuesday evenings School Board meeting one of the agenda items was the discussion to adjust this year's calendar to change March 27th from a professional development day to a student day, as a vehicle to make up one of the many snow days. The School Board did support this recommendation so March 27th is a student day and will be handled as a regular Friday in terms of dismissal.

For those of you keeping track we have used six snow days to date, and with March 27th becoming a student day the last day of school will be June 18th. (If we do not have any more snow days)

I am looking forward to spring!

post_text: Looking forward to hosting Dean Nichols from the University of Maine on his visit January 7th. Dean Nichols is in charge of the College of Education at the University of Maine and he and members of his team will be coming to meet with our new teacher orientation class. The purpose of the visit will be to check in with recent graduates from the University of Maine and to see how the teacher prep experience at the university aligns with the experiences new teachers are having in the field. The conversation should be very interesting and we see it as another way we can support our new teachers so our RSU 25 students are getting the best possible educational experience they can get.

When the dust settled the two teams went a combined 4 wins and 4 losses, with one of the teams coming in 9th place and the second team coming in 15th place out of 29 teams competing. A great showing, especially when you consider the other teams were high school teams. Thanks to everyone involved who made this a positive experience for our students.

post_text: I was very pleased to announce at last evening's school board meeting Bucksport High School has been recognized as a National BARR School of Academic Excellence. This recognition comes from the Building Assets and Reducing Risks program and with this honor BHS will be a model school for the program. Tomorrow Mr. Clifford, Mr. Tripp and I will be presenting at the Maine Principals Association fall conference and presenting the exciting results of the BARR program implementation at BHS. A formal presentation of the honor will be scheduled in January.

post_text: Open house at the high school this afternoon from 4:30 - 6 PM. Tours will be provided and there will be an opportunity to meet the architect and the general contractor responsible for this wonderful renovation. Hope to see you there!

post_text: The Finance Sub-Committee will be meeting today at 4:30 PM at the Central office. We adjusted the normal meeting time of this committee to accommodate the BHS open house tomorrow which will run from 4:30PM to 6PM. Members of the National Honor Society will be providing guided tours and representatives from Sheridan Corp will be on hand as well as Mark Wilcox the project architect.

post_text:
Ed Webster's presentation was well done and very interesting. Along with approximately 50 other folks I enjoyed the original photos and the story of Adm. Peary's quest. The question of the night came from one of the youngest audience members who wanted to know if Adm. Peary saw Santa Claus when he was at the north pole. Mr. Webster shared there was no photographic evidence of such a meeting, but he was pretty sure they winked at each other.

Thank you to Evelyn Beaulieu and Susan Lamoreau for arranging Ed's visit and thanks to the Alamo and the Chamber of Commerce for their support and partnership in the event.
text:
Ed Webster's presentation was well done and very interesting. Along with approximately 50 other folks I enjoyed the original photos and the story of Adm. Peary's quest. The question of the night came from one of the youngest audience members who wanted to know if Adm. Peary saw Santa Claus when he was at the north pole. Mr. Webster shared there was no photographic evidence of such a meeting, but he was pretty sure they winked at each other.

Thank you to Evelyn Beaulieu and Susan Lamoreau for arranging Ed's visit and thanks to the Alamo and the Chamber of Commerce for their support and partnership in the event.

post_text: Looking forward to going to the Alamo this evening at 7 PM to listen to Ed Webster's talk on Admiral Peary and the building of his ship. Ed had been presenting in our schools this week and has done a wonderful job connecting with the students and sharing his experiences climbing Mt. Everest.

post_text: There will be a public open house at Bucksport High School Tuesday November 18th from 4:30PM - 6 PM. Students from the National Honor Society will lead tours, a chance to meet the architect and contractor, and a short rededication.

post_text: Ed Webster will also be at the Alamo Thursday, November 13th at 7PM. Ed will be presenting his research on the connection between our region and Admiral Perry. He is very excited to share his research and information with the people of Bucksport, Orland, Prospect, and Verona Island. I am looking forward to this!

post_text: We are excited to welcome Ed Webster to RSU 25. Ed Webster will be working with all of our schools sharing his experience as an author and his experiences climbing Mount Everest. Ed will be visiting us Nov 12, 13, & 14.

post_text:
Thank you to the RSU 25 community for supporting our referendum to repair the Miles Lane Roof and update the playground.
Congratulations to Mindy Stegner and Tom Foster for being elected to another 3 year term, Peter Clair for a 2 year term and Scott Frasier for a 1 year term for our school board.
